author: Sharon Nunn
title: U.S. Durable-Goods Orders Rose 2.6% in March
text:
WASHINGTON—Demand for long-lasting U.S. factory goods rose in March due to increased aircraft orders, but an underlying proxy for business investment fell for the second time in three months.
Orders for durable goods—manufactured products intended to last at least three years, such as stoves and industrial robots—increased a seasonally adjusted 2.6% in March from the prior month, the Commerce Department said Thursday. Meanwhile, a business-investment gauge, new orders for nondefense capital goods excluding aircraft, declined...
